But if I had to point to the one film that still got me thinking it'd be Boots Riley's
incredibly weird and provocative debut film, Sorry To Bother You.
The film is an absurdist critique of capitalism and tells the story of Cassius Green, a
telemarketer who sacrifices his identity, his relationships and his morality in his quest to ascend up the corporate ladder.
But it would be unfair to reduce this film simply to the label of anti-capitalist. It does more than point
its finger and say capitalism bad and that's what I want to talk about here. In my view, the film
deemphasizes simple economic arguments as a critique against modern capitalism.
It's not just saying Group A isn't getting paid what they deserve while Group B is getting paid more than they deserve, therefore
there's an injustice. Rather
the thrust of the film is to portray the real psychological effects of these injustices and how the flaws in human nature
fuel the system. Wherever you land on the political spectrum,
I think you'll find something interesting, unique and nuanced in this film.

The idea here is that in order to retain a workforce, management needs to be able to convince its employees that their needs are being
provided for. In the past, management has been able to compensate its employees but workers are increasingly motivated by the need for
self-actualization, they need to feel like they are truly part of something greater than themselves or doing something positive.
Whatever! And so this song and dance is playing in which we all pretend reality is otherwise. In theory,

But just as the workers are forced to wear certain personas, Steve Lyft's outward charm is just that, a useful

People have complicated reasons for wanting to get rich beyond
satiating their basic needs. Men especially want to increase their attractiveness to women and many are seeking the self-actualization
that comes with being proficient at something. But to satisfy those needs, we are forced by society to enter into bad faith, forced to adopt
multiple personas. For the black community
especially this means code-switching between white identities,
stereotypically black identities and their authentic selves. This creates an identity
crisis in which the professional persona takes over the authentic personality. Workers also feel guilt over
participating in a system that is immoral. To counteract these psychological problems,
the management styles at big corporations have fundamentally shifted.
They're now aimed to alleviate guilt, make workers feel included and self-actualized so that they don't rebel
against the system and can be more easily
exploited monetarily. In the film's conclusion, the billionaire character reveals his plan to turn his
lower-level workers into these freaky half horse/half human creatures, equi sapiens, literal beasts of burden.
Here, the critique of capitalism is at its most obvious.
If you're at the bottom of the hierarchy, you must surrender your body and your dignity to the system.
But the more interesting critique, the one that we've been talking about is if you attempt to ascend through the ranks of capitalism,
you must sacrifice your inner identity, your individuality and your morality. In doing so, the film
transcends the simple economic argument against our current system and instead depicts the psychological wound that participating in this system
inevitably creates .But thankfully, more than that,
it depicts a way out, as well. In its conclusion,
Cassius begins to live a morally righteous life, to live authentically.
And the film posits that we must do this on an individual level. We must commit ourselves to opposing injustice
even if this means financial sacrifice because once we do, we can become effective
leaders of collective movements that have a real chance to change the system.
